_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The chlorine systems at the Carlsbad Municipal Water District (MWD) Maerkle Facility are used for the treatment of potable water used for distribution to the City of Carlsbad.  Chlorine is stored as a liquefied compressed gas in typical one-ton containers at two stations located at the Maerkle Facility:  Lower Maerkle, and Upper Maerkle.  As stated online, "Carlsbad Water Operations Department is responsible for a variety of behind the scenes services that keep our city running smoothly.  We are "At Your Service" and committed to providing top quality service to the Carlsbad community."



Carlsbad MWD's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain safety and environmental programs that promote a safe environment for all employees as well as the surrounding communities.  The Utilities Manager and Water Operations Supervisor are responsible for various inspections of the chlorine facilities to ensure compliance, and to oversee the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP), safe work practices such as Confined Space and Respiratory Protection, manufacturer-recommended maintenance and inspections, emergency response planning with the local fire department and San Diego County HazMat Team, as well as the Risk Management Plan that is also on file with the San Diego County CUPA.



Carlsbad MWD has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained by the department.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  Emergency

response policies and protocols were recently coordinated with the Carlsbad Fire Department and the San Diego County Hazardous Incident Response Team (HIRT) to ensure a mutual understanding of roles and responsibilities during a chlorine emergency situation.



Carlsbad MWD has formal and informal facility training programs for all employees.  Hazardous Materials training, (Awareness Level, 8-Hour HAZWOPER), is given to all water operations staff.  These operators are allowed to go onsite and assess a potential emergency from outside the stations.  All employees receive specific chlorine-related training during new employee orientation, as well as extensive refresher training that is conducted on a continual basis.  Operators are trained to call for outside assistance (911 and/or San Diego HazMat Team) to respond to a chlorine release.





STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Carlsbad Municipal Water District Maerkle Facility (5203 Sunny Creek Road, Carlsbad, California) is owned and operated by Carlsbad MWD (5950 El Camino Real, Carlsbad, California).  The facility is located approximately 1 mile north of the intersection of El Camino Real and Palomar Airport Road.  The facility is situated near the boundaries of the cities of Vista and Oceanside.



Two very similar chlorine water treatment systems are utilized at the facility:  Lower Maerkle and Upper Maerkle.  The chlorine systems were re-designed in 1995 accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations.  Each station is equipped with controlled access and security monitoring.  The Water Operations Department maintains a rotating Duty Operator who is on call 24/7 should any abnormal conditions arise.



The Maerkle Facility is a 111 acre site that consists of a ten million gallon distribution reservoir, a 600 acre foot long-term storage impound, one pumping/disinfection facility (Lower Maerkle), one impound disinfection facility (Upper Maerkle), related pressure control stations,

meter stations, and a caretaker's residence.  The site is normally unmanned (with the exception of the caretaker's residence).  Operators visit the site daily to monitor key parameters of the systems and to verify that there are no abnormal conditions.



** Lower Maerkle Station



A maximum of five (5) one-ton containers of chlorine can be stored in the chlorine room at any one time.  Empty containers are also stored in the chlorine room until being picked up by the chlorine vendor during the next chemical delivery.



Two (2) one-ton containers are on-line at any one time where one is in operation and the other is on standby.  The on-line containers are each placed on a digital scale that indicates the remaining weight of chlorine in each of the on-line one-ton containers to allow system operators to monitor usage and plan ahead for ordering more chlorine.  The chlorine system is operated entirely under vacuum conditions with a vacuum regulator attached to each of the one-ton container valves.  Each one-ton container is positioned so that the valves are vertically aligned.  The system connections are made at the top container valve to ensure that chlorine gas (not liquid) is drawn out of the container.

 

Chlorine gas is drawn from operating on-line one-ton container through an automatic switchover / vacuum regulator.  The automatic switchover regulator valves control which container is actively feeding chlorine to the vacuum regulator.  A vacuum (negative pressure) is created when process water is pumped through the injectors.  This flow generates a vacuum which opens the vacuum regulator.  If a loss of vacuum were to occur in the line downstream of the vacuum regulator, a diaphragm in the vacuum regulator will close, stopping any chlorine gas from escaping from the system.  Any chlorine in the piping upon loss of vacuum (downstream of the vacuum leak) will be drawn to the injection point and into the water solution.



Downstream of the vacuum regulator, chlo

rine gas is fed to manually-adjustable rotameters located in an adjacent room.  The chlorine can be distributed to various points in the water system as needed based on water sampling results.  Each process feeds chlorine gas into solution at an injector where it is mixed with water, which eliminates the hazard of the chlorine gas.



The chlorine systems are integrated into the Water Operations Department's SCADA system, which provides remote access to system parameters and operating conditions, as well as security monitoring.  The SCADA system provides a readout of the weight of the one-ton container that is on-line, status of facility access doors, and leak detection monitoring.



Lead fuse plugs that included in the design of the one-ton containers are designed to yield and melt between 158?F and 165?F to relieve pressure and prevent rupture of the container in case of fire or other exposure to high temperatures.



The one-ton containers are stored in the Chlorine Tank Room, which is protected by a scrubber with a capacity to neutralize up to 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas.  The scrubber is activated based on the alarm status of a chlorine leak detector located in the Chlorine Tank Room.  The scrubber system and auxiliary components (ex: air blower) are function tested on a monthly basis by water operators.



** Upper Maerkle Station



The maximum quantity of chlorine maintained at the Upper Maerkle Station is 2 one-ton containers (4,000 pounds).



The design and operation of the chlorine system (upstream of the chlorinators) at the Upper Maerkle Station is very similar to that of the Lower Maerkle Station.  Only two rotameters are used at the Upper Maerkle Station.  Prior to injection, the chlorine gas passes through a chlorine dioxide generator that used sodium hypochlorite as a reagent to create chlorine dioxide.  The process feeds this chlorine dioxide into solution at the injector where it is mixed with water.  Similar chlorine detection and scrubber sys

tems are located at the Upper Maerkle Station.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Carlsbad MWD chlorine systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety design is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the chlorine processes.  For example, the Carlsbad MWD treatment systems operate in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of chlorine, there are four mechanisms in the facility to minimize the impact: 1) chlorine gas detectors, 2) visual/audible alarms, 3) emergency chlorine scrubber system, and 4) halogen motorized automatic shut-off valves.



The chlorine detectors located in the chlorine rooms at both stations trigger both alarms and shut off actions, as well as notifying the Water Operations Duty Operator.  At 1ppm, the leak detection system activates an audible alarm and triggers the SCADA system to notify the Duty Operator.  At 3ppm, the audible and visual alarms are activated, the motorized automatic shut off valves are triggered to close the one-ton container valve (equipped with battery backup power), the scrubber is activated that draws in the contents of the room to be neutralized, and the SCADA system sends another message to the Duty Operator that the motorized automatic shut off valve was activated.



The scrubber runs until the detector senses less than 1 ppm chlorine concentration in the room.  The scrubber for each facility has a capacity to neutralize 2,000 pounds of chlorine with a 99%+ rate of effectiveness.



In the event of a power failure, vacuum regulators prevent chlorine from escaping the system.  A backup generator that is activated during a power outage is maintained onsite to power the chlorine systems and water pumps.  If vacuum conditions are c

ompromised, the vacuum regulators close to stop chlorine flow from the one-ton containers.  Chlorine vent lines are piped to ventilation intakes of the scrubber system.



Lead fuse plugs that included in the design of the one-ton containers are designed to yield and melt between 158?F and 165?F to relieve pressure and prevent rupture of the container in case of fire or other exposure to high temperatures.



There is also an emergency stop button located in the Chlorine Dioxide Generator Room at the Upper Maerkle Station and in the Chlorine Tank Room at the Lower Maerkle Station.  Activating the E-Stop button triggers the motorized halogen valves to close the ton-container valve of the active container.



In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices recommended by the Chlorine Institute.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the accident history at the Carlsbad MWD Upper and Lower Maerkle Stations conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation study (April 2019), there have been no accidental releases of chlorine at the either the Upper or the Lower Maerkle Stations that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds in the last five years (April 2014 to April 2019) or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of hazardous material for the Five-Year Accident History at the facility.

In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chlorine release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Carlsbad MWD has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of the PSM/RMP document, which is maintained by the Water Operations Department and updated as necessary.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



  1.)  To save lives.

  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.

  3.)  To protect the environment.

  4.)  To minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, chlorine health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  Emergency response policies and protocols were recently coordinated with the Carlsbad Fire Department and the San Diego County Hazardous Incident Response Team (HIRT) to ensure a mutual understanding of roles and responsibilities during a chlorine emergency situation.  This included familiarization training classes, as well as mock release / rescue scenarios.



Since the facility is normally unmanned, water operators are typically the only personnel on site.  In case of a chlorine leak detection at the facility, the on-call Duty Operator is alerted via SCADA system.  The Duty Operator alerts the MWD Supervisor and Utilities Manager and immediately responds to the alarm.  Upon arrival, the Duty Operator determines whether or not the Fire Department should be called to respond to the emergency based on the severity of the incident.  The duty operator assignment is made on a rotating basis between the various trained and qualified Water Operations staff.  Each water operator has the necessary hazardous materials training to be considered "qualified" to assess the severity of a potential chlorine

leak.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation study performed in April 2019 provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the Carlsbad MWD Maerkle Facility.  The PHA Revalidation study included a discussion of any changes to the chlorine systems since the previous PHA study, a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the previous PHA study, a discussion of the facility's accident history dating back five years, the completion of chlorine industry checklists, and the detailed HAZOP analysis that reviewed potential hazards and operability issues with the chlorine systems.  A Three-Year Compliance Audit was also conducted in June 2019 that identified compliance-related issues to improve.



The Water Operations Department PSM Committee meets routinely (typically quarterly) to ensure that items recommended in studies such as PHAs, Compliance Audits, Seismic Assessments, and regulatory inspections are addressed in a timely manner.



Carlsbad MWD also plans to improve safety as follows:



 - Continued involvement of water operations staff in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies and procedures.

 - Attendance and participation of key personnel in industry groups, such as AWWA, ensure the department is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques implemented to encourage safety.

 - Conducting routine RMP and PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by water operations staff, contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.

 - Continuing training and certification program for all water operations staff that is overseen by the State Water Resources Control Board.
